posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
I created a program that scrapes GitHub to identify public repositories of robot code for teams ranked in the top 300 by EPa. This collection serves as a valuable reference for anyone involved in FTC Robotics competitions. You can access the dataset [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DM9e6BfHAz6vgunDjd_3omCpgrsXfdrn7atWPzjFnRU/edit?usp=sharing). Collaboration and categorization efforts are encouraged to enhance its usefulness as a programming resource.

While focusing primarily on top teams provides a useful starting point, it's important to recognize that not all teams adhere to consistent coding conventions. My program identifies projects posted in 2025, which includes some older materials from teams that may not have followed best practices. A few teams, like SPAM, introduced new code shortly after publication, so they won't appear in this dataset until re-scraped later.

The script uses criteria such as `‚ÄúprojectYear‚Äù: ‚Äú2025‚Äù` to filter results, acknowledging contributions from @kn4 who suggested this approach. This method inadvertently includes some 2024 offseason code as well, highlighting the potential benefits of community-driven organization. If you have suggestions or encounter issues, feel free to reach out or share any accidental commits you'd like removed.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
Not a good idea

Honestly, I just couldn't think of a better way to make it open to contributions, and I didn't think malice would be an issue at all. Any ideas for another approach? I'm still considering that...

Additionally, if anyone has ideas on how to categorize entries‚Äîwhether they contain main robot code, supplemental material, or other public repositories‚Äîthey're welcome to share their thoughts. I've already started marking them accordingly...

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: You can enable suggesting changes without editing. Gavin0 asks, 'any ideas for another way?'

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, Google Sheets does not currently support that feature, though it works in Docs. I‚Äôve switched it to allow commenting only. If you‚Äôre interested in editing access, let me know, and I‚Äôll share it directly.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked: The text is: I prefer to sort by the most important metric: total number of codebases. I guess we still have some work to do.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: We're finally in the top. A bunch of those listed are forks by our kids to practice coding their own robot during the off-season.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: The Blue Alliance links to teams' GitHub organization. It would be great to get a list that could be imported there.
I am surprised 3481 isn't higher there!

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

"Honestly, I couldn‚Äôt think of a better way to make it open to contributions and didn‚Äôt consider malice as an issue. Any ideas for another approach?

Not sure if this is what you need, but a Google Form linked to Google Sheets could allow people to submit their codes without exposing the data already displayed."

This version removes all HTML tags, keeps the core message, and ensures clarity with proper grammar and punctuation.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: On a related note, some time ago I made a search shortcut to do a github code search to find any individual team‚Äôs repo in a similar manner: https://github.com/search?q=/"projectYear"/2025%3A+%5C%5Cs%2B%5C"teamNumber%22%3A+%s%5Cn%2F+path%3Awpilib_preferences.json&type=code (instructions to add it to Chrome at https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/95426).

link_counts.title: Set default search engine and site search shortcuts - Computer - Google Chrome Help

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked: If you sent this to Discord a while back, then you might be the one who got the wpilibpreferences searching idea, thank you!

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: I think you can do a protected range in sheets, and protect the known good data.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: Maybe it's about time we changed our repo name from "placeholder-2025".

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I love names like this that never get updated. At one of our competitions this year, we were working out of a branch called temp-auton-testing.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: I decided to manually search all the repos myself. I used the code search API to find all the repos at once, splitting the searches by digits to avoid hitting GitHub‚Äôs limit of 1000 results per search. There are a few inaccuracies due to copied example projects.

posts.name: Ari
posts.cooked: It seems like our repo is actually updated with the bot name; however, it isn't reflected on the first spreadsheet.

posts.name: Ethan C
posts.cooked: Hi, can I get edit access to add 2022's codebase? Additionally, I would like to attempt labeling some of the codebases by programming language.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: You could probably just look for ‚Äúrobot‚Äù and then you have the extension ready.

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: Might need to talk to some mentors about making all of our repos public so we can analyze some metrics. Here‚Äôs an image showing the metrics [wink].
